notesStmt.note: Any special notes on this text? (optional)

sourceDesc.p: Information on named entities in this file has been extracted from files in the Digital Mitford Archive.

person.note: Rebecca Parker is pursuing an M.A. in Digital Humanities at Loyola University in Chicago. She graduated with a B.A. in English Literature and Social Sciences from the University of Pittsburgh at Greensburg, where she has worked as an assistant for the Center for the Digital Text. She is currently working on a digital archive of her own. Her project, The Restoration of Nell Nelson, started in spring 2014 as research for her capstone thesis in history. The Nell Nelson archive intends to restore the importance of a female investigative reporter that exposed the harmful effects of industrialization in Chicago at the turn of the twentieth century. Parker’s interest in Digital Humanities stemmed from her involvement on the Digital Mitford Project working as Dr. Beshero-Bondar’s Green Scholar. She is helping to prepare a digital edition of Mary Russell Mitford’s journal of 1819-1823.

roleName.affiliation: State University of New York, Potsdam

person.note: Nate Young graduated in 2022 with a B.F.A. in Creative Writing from the State University of New York at Potsdam. He completed an internship with Dr. Wilson as a Digital Mitford Research Assistant in Spring 2022, focusing on letter transcribing and description.

roleName.affiliation: State University of New York, Potsdam

person.note: Danya Shembesh graduated in 2022 with a B.F.A. in Creative Writing from the State University of New York at Potsdam. She completed an internship with Dr. Wilson as a Digital Mitford Research Assistant in Spring 2022, focusing on letter transcribing.

roleName.affiliation: State University of New York, Potsdam

person.note: Kyanna Hastings graduates in 2023 with a B.F.A. in Creative Writing from the State University of New York at Potsdam. She completed an internship with Dr. Wilson as a Digital Mitford Research Assistant in 2021-2022, focusing on letter transcribing and research.

roleName.affiliation: State University of New York, Potsdam

person.note: Kemton Lampart graduated in 2022 with a B.S. in Business Administration from the State University of New York at Potsdam, Watertown campus. He completed an internship with Dr. Wilson as a Digital Mitford Research Assistant in fall 2021, focusing on letter transcribing.

org.note: A family who lived at Moore House, Shinfield.

org.orgName: Unmarried daughters of the Broughton family.

org.note: A family who lived at Moore House, Shinfield.
A family who, according to Francis Needham’s notes, lived on Minster Street in Reading, over their China shop.
Lived at Farley Hill, where Mitford visited them.
Lived at Farley Hill, where Mitford visited them.
The family of Mr. Sherwood, a local doctor.
In Mitford's lifetime, the Whigs developed into a formalized political party under the leadership of Charles James Fox, standing in opposition to the party.

person.note: Manservant at Bertram House in 1819. He and his brother George buried Mossy.
Maidservant at Bertram House in 1819.
Dined at Bertram House with the Mitfords and Mr. Parfitt in 1819. Forename unknown. Dates unknown. Source: Journal.
Mitford corresponded with him in 1819. Original member of the Ilsley Coursing Society, with George Mitford. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
An acquaintance of Mitford in 1819. May be the relation of Maria Bailey Kirby. Dates unknown.
Associated with Mr. Johnson and Miss Johnson. Mitford dined with them at Seymour Court. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Mitford corresponded with him in 1819. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Daughter of Colonel Anstruther. Mitford visited her in Reading in 1819. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Mitford corresponded with him in 1819 and visited his daughter, Miss Anstruther, in Reading. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Lived in Reading, where Mitford called upon her in 1819. Forename unknown. Dates unknown. Source: Journal.

birth.placeName: Thornton, West Riding of Yorkshire, England

death.placeName: Haworth, West Riding of Yorkshire, England

person.note: Yorkshire novelist and poet.

A correspondent of Mitford's, to whom she writes at 11 East Cliff, Brighton. William Colessuggests that this could be a summer address, and that she was a resident of Reading. She was courted by Dr. Valpy in October 1823. Forename unknown. Possibly the daughter of Mrs. Brooke and Mr. Brooke. Source: Letter from William Coles to Needham, 10 November 1957 , Needham Papers, .
Forename unknown. Dates unknown. Possibly the mother of Miss Brooke and spouse of Mr. Brooke.
Forename unknown. The father of Miss Brooke and spouse of Mrs. Brooke.
Victorian poet, married to Elizabeth Barrett Browning. Important philsopher-poet and practitioner of the dramatic monologue poetic form. His early poetry was influenced by Percy Bysshe Shelley.
Mitford's Journal entry of April 28, 1819 records that she lived in Bedford and died in childbirth. Forename unknown. Dates unknown
Mitford met him at the Webbs in 1819. Source: Journal. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Brought Mitford wildflowers in pots in 1819. Source: Journal. Dates unknown.

Son of Rev. Richard Harrington and Jane Champernowne who took the name and arms of Champernowne in 1774, after the death without issue of the last direct male heir, Rawlin Champernowne. Member of the family of high-ranking landed gentry, Champernowne of Dartington, near Totnes, in Devon. With his wife Louise Buller Champernowne, amateur artists and leading art collectors in the early 19th century; his collection was sold at Christie's on June 30, 1820. They were admitted to sketch in the Townley Gallery of the British Museum in 1809. Friend of William Elford. M.P. for Saltash in 1806 and High Sherriff of Devon in 1811. They also lived at 10 Montagu Street in London. Succeeded by his son Henry. Friend of Samuel Rogers and etcher Francis Towne.

death.placeName: Northampton General Lunatic Asylum, Northampton, Northamptonshire, England

person.note: Called the peasant poet, Clare worked as an agricultural laborer and manservant.

Miss James was her companion and, with Mrs. Stuart, widow of the Archbishop of Armagh, a legatee of her estate. Daughter of Johnson Macaree, Saxon scholar, and Anne Knowler. Paternal descendant of a Huguenot refugee family who emigrated in the 16th century; Maternal descendant of the Elstob family, Saxon scholars and connections of Welsh royalty. Lived in London with her husband Anthony (1758-1830), who worked on the Stock Exchange. They retired to the Priory, a home in Canterbury built around some outbuildings of St. Augustine's Monastery, where some of the ruins of St. Ethelbert's Tower featured in her garden. Also a friend and correspondent of writer Anne Macvicar Grant. Sources: Letters and Correspondence of Mrs. Grant of Laggan and obituary in Gentleman's Magazine (1835): 544-545.
Jesse Cliff gave the Mitford family elderly bantams in 1819.
Lived in Earley. Owned a neighboring meadow near Bertram House

A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1837 and one of the signatories on her request for a Royal Literary Fund pension. Son of George Dawson of Osgodby Hall, Yorkshire and Elmira Reeves of Arborfield House, Berkshire, he inherited the Arborfield Park estate in 1832. He dismantled the existing Jacobean manor house and built a new mansion, Arborfield House by 1837.
Inherited Moore Place estate in Shinfield from his father William. After his death, the estate descended to his wife Isabella, who later married Thomas Owst.
Spouse of William Hanson Dearsley and lived with him at Moore Place in Shinfield until his death in 1825. After his death, she inherited Moore Place.
An acquaintance of Mitford in 1819. The spouse of Mrs. Dobbs. She lists their address in her Journal as 27 Hatton Gardens in London. Dates unknown.

An acquaintance of Mitford and friend of Elizabeth James, who is remembered in her will. She lists her address as Five Ways, then a village in the parish of Edgbaston, Warwickshire, England, now a region in central Birmingham. Unmarried businesswoman and property owner in her own right, she traded as a wine merchant and metal factor between 1769 and 1785. She traded as Florry and Walker with William Walker between 1785 and 1799, and then retired in 1799 to Five Keys. See Christine Wiskin, Women, Finance and Credit in England, c. 1780-1826, Ph.D. thesis, U of Warwick.
Manservant at Bertram House in 1819; dismissed on September 15, 1820, when the Mitfords moved to Three Mile Cross, a much smaller establishment. He and his brother Frank buried Mossy. Dates unknown.
Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Forename unknown. Dates unknown. Local doctor, not the same person as Henry Harris, the Covent Garden Theatre manager.
Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
With his father, a Watlington brewer, and later the spouse of Jane Webb. They had two children, Susan Jane (1815-1898) and William Webb (1818-1899).
A Watlington brewer, the spouse of Mrs. Hayward and father of William Hayward.
A Watlington brewer, the brother of William Hayward.

Friend of Mary Russell Mitford, the daughter of James Webb and Jane Elizabeth Ogbourn. Baptized on March 3, 1797. Sister of Elizabeth (called Eliza) and Mary Webb and niece of the elder Mary Webb, Aunt Mary . Spouse of William Hayward, they married 23 September, 1816. In Needham’s papers, he notes from the Berkshire Directorythat she lived on Broad street, presumably in Wokingham, Berkshire.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitfordbetween 1839 and 1849.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford. Spouse of Margaret Wilkinson Hughes and father of Jane Hughes Senior.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford. Spouse of John Hughes. Second daughter of Thomas Wilkinson of Stokesley Hall in Yorkshire.

A friend and correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1829 and 1855. Mitford wrote to her at Castle Martyr, Ireland, and at No. 1 Charles Street, Twickenham. Grandniece of playwright Robert Jephson.
An acquaintance of Mitfordin 1819. Mitford visited her in Wokingham, along with the Webb family and James Wheeler. Sister of barrister Henry Jeremy.

Brother of Mitford friend Caroline Jeremy. Called to the bar in 1818 at Middle Temple. Served as Recorder for Wokingham, police magistrate at Greenwich, and magistrate at Union Hall. Author of several law books and histories of English law.
Alumni of Reading School and Trinity College, Cambridge. Rector of Babington from 1810 to 1872.
Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Friend of the Mitford family, who offered the family lumber to build a cottage in 1818. Source: L'Estrange.
A friend of Mary Russell Mitford and soi-distant cousin of Elizabeth Barrett Browning.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1853. Spouse of Fanny Grenfell Kingsley.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford. Spouse of Charles Kingsley.

A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford. Trinity College, Oxford scholar and Church of England clergyman. Travelled extensively in Portugal and Belgium. Published essays, sermons, and a travel book on Portugal.

An acquaintance of Mary Russell Mitford and a shop assistant to Reading bookseller with premises at 37 and 39 London Street, George Lovejoy. Langley purchased the business upon Lovejoy's death in 1882 and expanded it. She operated the bookselling, stationery, and circulating library business under the name The Lovejoy and Southern Counties Library. She published at least two books by Elizabeth Waterhouse under the imprint Lovejoy's Library.
An associate of the Webb family in 1819. May be a relative of Jane Ogbourn Webb, whose mother's paternal name was Lawrence. Dates unknown.

A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1840 and 1850 and a Reading bookseller with premises at 37 and 39 London Street. Father of Martha (Patty) Lovejoy. His shop assistant was Eliza Langley. He established a general subscription circulating library in 1832.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1846. Daughter of George Lovejoy and his wife Alice Beckwith Cecil.

death.placeName: St. John's Wood, London, Middlesex, England

person.note: A friend and correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1828 and 1853. Fashionable portrait painter and mezzotint engraver who painted both Mary Russell Mitford and her father George.
May also be spelled Maddison. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.

Son of wealthy merchant and Bank of England director Ebenezer Maitland, he married heiress Bethia Ellis and took the name of Fuller Maitland in 1807, by the wish of his wife's aunt. South Sea company director. Member of Parliament for Lostwithiel, Wallingford, and Chippenham. Elected Sheriff in Berkshire and Breconshire.
One of Mitford's greyhounds at Bertram House in 1819.

Mitford's letters in December 1820 indicate that Henry Marsh was involved in a local political tiff with Henry Hart Milman. The rift between Henry Marsh and H.H. Milman is well documented. See The History of Parliament online.

A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1840 and 1843. A student of Joseph Woods and James Savage, he also studied architecture at the Royal Academy. Worked as an architect, civil engineer, and manager of industrial works that included canals, colleries, and railways. Worked with Savage on the tunnel under the Thames, later completed by Brunel. With Beasley, designed the first English Opera House, located in the Strand.

A paternal relative and correspondent of Mary Russell Mitfordbetween 1816 and 1843. Served in the Royal Navy as Captain, retiring as Rear Admiral. In her early years, Mitford refers to him as Captain Osbaldeston. He was a talented amateur artist, and learned engraving from Thomas Bewick and collaborated with Prideaux John Selby on several important works on British birds. He later became the 29th Lord Mitford of Mitford, Northumberland, England, upon the death of his elder brother.
Mentioned in Francis Needham’s biographical listings of people in Mitford’s circles or relevant to her work.

An acquaintance of Mary Russell Mitford. Moderate Anglo-Irish Whig politician who held strong unionist views and led the opposition to the nationalist agenda of Daniel O'Connell, who advocated dissolving the Acts of Union 1800. He supported Catholic emancipation, the world-wide abolition of slavery, and state-funded education, and he criticized the British government's response to the famine in Ireland. M.P. for Limerick and for Cambridge. He served as Chancellor of the Exchequer and Comptroller General of the Exchequer.

Solicitor at various addresses in Lincoln Inn Fields, London; and at Friar Street, Reading. He was an articled clerk in Abingdon. Prominent citizen of Reading. Spouse of Mrs. Newbery. Name variously spelled Newbery and Newberry. He was sued for fraudulent handling of a client's money and subsequently declared bankrupt in 1835. Source: Reports of Cases Argued and Determined in the English Courts of Common Law, vol. 31 (1853): 62-63.
Spouse of Jacob Newbery. Name variously spelled Newbery and Newberry. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Mitford called on her at Wokingham. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Forename unknown. Dates unknown.

An acquaintance of Mary Russell Mitford between 1847 and 1855. Bank of England superintendant, Poor Law Commissioner, and later Secretary to the Poor Law Commission. Created Knight Commander of the Bath in 1851. Father of Jane Nicholls Ouvry. Source: Visitation of England and Wales, vol. 2 (1894): 49-5.
An acquaintance of Mary Russell Mitford between 1847 and 1855. Mother of Jane Nicholls Ouvry and spouse of George Nicholls.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1841 and 1843. Unitarian clergyman, theologian, and church leader.

death.placeName: the Vicarage, Leighton Buzzard, Buckinghamshire, England

person.note: A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1847 and 1855. Spouse of the Rev. Peter Thomas Ouvry, vicar of Leighton Buzzard, Buckinghamshire, England. Daughter of George Nicholls.

An acquaintance of Mary Russell Mitford between 1847 and 1855. Spouse of Jane Nicholls Ouvryand vicar of Leighton Buzzard, Buckinghamshire, England. The Ouvry family were Hugenot refugees from France during the 17th century.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Spouse of Mrs. Payn. They live near Seymour Court. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Spouse of Mr. Payn. They live near Seymour Court. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.

death.placeName: St. George's Chapel, Windsor Castle, Windsor, Berkshire, England

person.note: A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1852. Vicar of St. Andrews Church, Sonning and Canon at St. George's Chapel, Windsor Castle.
Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Owner of a field near Bertram House. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Actor, author, and literary celebrity, the friend of Mary Robinson and Sarah Siddons. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1810.
Spouse of Mrs. Raggett. In Mitford's Journal in 1819, she records that he is blind. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.

Spouse of Mrs. Raggett. In Mitford's Journal in 1819, she indicates that Mrs. Raggett is her cousin, who offers her the position of companion, but she refuses to leave her father George. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.

Friend of Mitford and Miss Jamesin 1819. The 6th daughter of George Ramsay (1769-1810) of Edinburgh. Dedicatee of Mitford's On the Departure of a Friend to Lisbon for the Recovery of Her Health. Emily James accompanied her to Lisbon before her death in 1819. Mitford notes that two of her sisters also died in young womanhood, likely Eleanor and Helen.
Dates unknown.

A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1832. Newspaper and magazine founder, journalist, editor. He reported on events in France for the Examiner, served as uncredited editor of the New Monthly Magazine in the 1820s, and edited a number of other journals in the 1830s and 1840s. He then turned to writing novels, nonfiction works for adults and children, biographies of William Beckford and Thomas Campbell, and volumes of autobiography.

A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1838. Studied at Norwich Grammar School, led by Richard Valpy's brother Edward. Travelled extensively in Europe and translated works from several European languages into English. Wrote for The Times between 1840 and 1855. His experiences as clerk of appeal and registrar for the Privy Council enabled him to write authoritatively on foreign affairs, including the events of the Crimean War.
Actor, author, and public celebrity.

person.persName: Constance Charlotte Eliza Lennox, Lady Russell
person.note: A correspondent and friend of Mary Russell Mitford, when she moved to a cottage near Swallowfield at the end of her life. Spouse of Sir George Russell, fourth baronet. Daughter of Lord Arthur Lennox. Author of Swallowfield and its Owners (1910).
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1831. Dates unknown.
Servant at Bertram House, dismissed on September 15, 1820, when the Mitfords moved to Three Mile Cross, a much smaller establishment. Surname unknown.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1835 and 1840. Brother of Catherine Sedgwick, spouse of novelist Susan Anne Livingston and father of author and lawyer Theodore Sedgwick.

Social reformer and relief worker during the Franco-Prussian War, and co-founder of the Metropolitan Association for Befriending Young Servants (MABYS). In 1873, became an assistant inspector of workhouses, making her the first female paid civil servant in the UK. She was the daughter of John Hughes and sister of writer Thomas Hughes.

Important naturalist and illustrator in the 1820s, 30s, and 40s, friend and neighbor of Robert Osbaldeston Mitford, with whom he collaborated on several volumes on British birds. He also contributed to Jardine's Naturalist's Library and authored a volume on British trees.

A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1805 and a moderate Tory Member of Parliament for Reading from 1796 to 1820. Not to be confused with his son, Charles Shaw-Lefevre, 1st Viscount Eversley, who became spaker of the House of Commons. Born Charles Shaw, he took the name Shaw Lefevre in 1789 and retired from legal practice in 1790 after inheriting from his father-in-law. He was an East India company investor and held interests in banking and insurance.

person.persName: Mary Anne Scott Townshend Addington, Lady Sidmouth
person.note: A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1830. Second wife of Henry Addington, 1st Viscount Sidmouth.
Called at Bertram House in 1819. Dates unknown.
An associate of Mr. Elliott, possibly an attorney. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Possibly the father of Emily Stevenson. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Possibly the daughter of Mr. StevensonDates unknown.
Mitford met her when dining at Mr. Green's in 1820. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Poet laureate of the UK from 1850 to 1892, following Wordsworth. Buried in Westminster Abbey.
In Mitford's time, a captain retired from the Royal West regiment of the London militia. Later became a magistrate and served as mayor of Reading.
Spouse of William Tuppen. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Friend of the Mitfords who visited Bertram House and Three Mile Cross. Likely the spouse of Mrs. Voules. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Friend of the Mitfords. She adopts one of Molly's puppies in 1820. Likely the spouse of Mr. Voules. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Friend of the Mitfords who visited Bertram House. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.
Mitford correspondent in 1819. Forename unknown. Dates unknown.

A friend of Mitford in 1819-1823. Mitford visited him in Wokingham, along with the Webb family and Miss Jeremy. May be either James Wheeler (1766-1850), spouse of Catherine Bird Rogers Wheeler (1771-1852) or their son, James Wheeler (1792-1866), spouse of Harriet Horne, all of whom lived in Wokingham. James Wheeler, father and son, were both surgeons.

item.name: horse
Equus ferus caballus
Equus
Equidae
item.note: Domesticated horse; different breeds are all considered of the same species. There are seventeen breeds of horses and ponies considered native to the UK, including the English thoroughbred, a racing and riding breed descended from Arabian stock; the Hackney, a trotter; and Clydesdales and Shires, bred for heavy pulling and farm work. The stud book for UK horses is kept by Weatherbys.

item.name: Arabian horse
Equus ferus caballus
Equus
Equidae
item.note: A breed known for its stamina and athleticism, as well as its fine bone structure, arched neck, and highly-carried tail, were developed on the Arabian peninsula. The breed likely arrived in Europe around the time of the Crusades, as spoils of war, and became part of state and royal studs. James I introduced the breed to England in 1616 and others were imported in the 18th century to create modern racing breeds such as the English thoroughbred. Marengo, Napoleon's war horse, was an Arabian. Europeans travelling to the middle East in the 19th century began intensively collecting Arabians.

item.name: pony
Equus ferus caballus
Equus
Equidae
item.note: Small breeds of horse, often with stocky and heavy body types with round heads and shorter legs as well as thicker manes and tails. In the 19th century, used for pulling light vehicles, as mounts for women and children, They were also used as ack animals, such as the pit ponies used in British mining, bred from Hills and Dales ponies of the North of England. So-called polo ponies are usually standard-sized horses. There are seventeen breeds of horses and ponies considered native to the UK, including the Shetland pony.

item.name: donkey
Equus africanus asinus
Equus
Equidae
item.note: Domestic animal descended from the African wild ass, mostly used as draught or pack animals. In the UK, used as recreational mounts at seaside resorts. Spread throughout the Roman empire. Before the 1780s, called asses; the term may have changed to avoid vulgar connotations with similar-sounding terms like arse.

item.name: sheep
Ovis aries
Ovis
Bovidae
item.note: Domesticated grazing animals kept as livestock for their fleece and milk, and as meat. One of the earliest domesticated animals, descended from the mouflon of Europe and Asia. The UK continues to be a center of sheep production, as it was in the 19th century and earlier. Sheep feature in pastoral art and literature, fables and nursery rhymes, as well as in ancient world mythology and Abrahamic religions.

item.name: goat
Capra hircus
Capra
Bovidae
item.note: Domestic grazing animals kept for their milk, meat, and skins. One of the earliest domesticated animals, descended from the wild goat found in Eastern Europe and in Southwest Asia. Males are called billygoats and females nannygoats.

item.name: cow
Bos taurus
Bos
Bovidae
item.note: Large domesticated grazing animal raised as livestock for meat, milk, or hides. Cow is the term for female cattle and bull for males, although both are commonly referred to as cows. Also used as draught animals (called oxen) to pull carts or plows. One of the earliest domesticated animals, descended from two separate areas, one in the Near East (Turkey and northern Syria) and one in modern-day Pakistan. Many modern-day breeds are descended from cattle exported from the UK to the rest of the world between the l7th and early 20th century, including: Aberdeen Angus, Ayrshire, Belted Galloway, Blue Grey, Devon, Dexter, British White, British Friesian, English Longhorn, Gloucester, Guernsey, Hereford, Jersey, Kerry, and Shorthorn.

item.name: oxen
Bos taurus
Bos
Bovidae
item.note: Large, domesticated grazing animals, often castrated bullocks of larger cattle breeds such as Sussex. Called ox and oxen when trained as draught animals to pull carts or plows. Usually yoked to work in pairs.

item.name: domestic pig
Sus domesticus
Sus
Suidae
item.note: Large omnivorous domestic animal kept as livestock primarily for meat, but pig's bristles and hide are also used. Likely domesticated from wild boar in three separate areas: first in the Near East and China and later in Europe. By the 19th century, native UK breeds included: Tamworth, Large White, Large Black, British Lop, Berkshire, and Oxford Sandy and Black. The Berkshire is considered the oldest British breed; it's a stocky, medium-sized black pig with white patches and legs. The Oxford Sandy and Black developed in Oxfordshire in the 18th century; it's a medium-sized pig with reddish, sandy-colored skin and black patches.

item.name: European ferret
Mustela putorius
Mustela
Mustelidae
item.note: Carnivorous mammal native to Eurasia, North Africa, and the UK. Shorter and stouter than related species like weasels or stoats, it is dark brown with a dark mask and lighter underbelly and defends its territory by spraying a malodorous liquid. Domesticated for hunting vermin and hunted for pelts. In 18th and 19th century England, Scotland and Wales, were eradicated by gamekeepers and bounty hunters, who believed them to be a nuisance animal dangerous to poultry stock. Traditionally hunted in Britain in spring with mixed packs of dogs.

item.name: dog
Canis familiaris
Canis
Canidae
item.note: First animal species to be domesticated, before the developmment of farming, by hunter-gatherers more than fifteen thousand years ago. Descended from an ancient, now-extinct wolf species. Modern dog breeds were codified beginning in the late 19th century, with the rise of dog shows and set breed standards. Before that time, dogs were classified by appearance or function and any such may now be considered landrace, traditional, or heritage breeds. More than 50 named dog breeds originated in the UK. Breeds extant during the first half of the nineteenth century include: many terrier breeds in a range of sizes and coat types, originally bred to hunt vermin; several hounds, hunting dogs used to track or chase prey, such as the scenthounds (bloodhounds, harriers, fox hounds) and the sighthounds (greyhound, Irish Wolfhound, Scottish deerhound); mastiffs such as the English bulldog, Bullmastiff and English mastiff, used in blood sports and as guard dogs; sporting dogs used in bird hunting, such as setters and pointers; and many spaniels, including the Cavalier King Charles, Clumber, Sussex, English springer and English cocker spaniels. Now-extinct predecessor breeds include: Staghound, Buckhound, Talbot hound, Old English Bulldog, Norfolk and Tweed water spaniels, Black and Tan terrier, Cumberland sheepdog, English cur or drover's dog, Curley-coated retriever, English water spaniel, and English white terrier. Most so-called extinct breeds actually contributed bloodlines subsumed by later breeds.

item.name: Newfoundland dog
Canis familiaris
Canis
Canidae
item.note: Large, muscular working dog with a thick coat and webbed feet. Developed in eastern Canada to assist fishermen, they are genetically related to Irish water spaniels, Labrador retrievers, and Curly-Coated retrievers. Landseer or European Continental Type dogs with black and white coats, named for the English artist, also exist, and may be a separate breed. Sweet-tempered and loyal, they good with children and became known as nanny dogs. Nana, from Barrie's Peter Pan, was based on a black and white Landseer-type dog owned by Barrie.

item.name: terrier
Canis familiaris
Canis
Canidae
item.note: In the 19th century, terriers were categorized as short- or long-legged, as well as categorized informally by function, such as rat terrier or fox terrier. UK terrier breeds appear in a range of sizes and coat types, and were originally bred to be fearless and agile in order hunt vermin (rats, foxes) underground. Terriers were used in blood sports such as rat-catching. Terriers and bulldog-terrier mixes were also used in dogfighting. Two notable heritage breeds, now extinct, include the black-and-tan terrier and the English white terrier. A terrer named Viper appears in one of Mitford's stories.

item.name: mongrel dog
Canis familiaris
Canis
Canidae
item.note: Term used in the UK for mixed or indeterminate breed dogs.

item.name: spaniel
Canis familiaris
Canis
Canidae
item.note: In Mitford's time, spaniels were classified as land or water types, and as springer (larger) and cocker (smaller) types, although springers and cockers may have come from the same litter. They are gun dogs bred to flush or spring game birds. They were also used to hunt rabbits, sometimes alongside greyhounds. They may have solid or parti-colored coats in black, liver, red, or golden, with tan masking and trim, roan patching, or ticked spots. The most common color is liver (dark brown/chocolate) and white. The Sussex spaniel, first recorded in 1795, is a stocky spaniel with a distinctive golden-brown colored coat and hazel eyes. The spaniel, Flush, gifted by Mitford to Elizabeth Barrett Browning, had a golden-brown coat and hazel eyes, as described in her poem To Flush, My Dog. Molly was a white spaniel with a wavy coat, perhaps with water spaniel ancestry. The Mitfords raised and bred spaniels kept as companion animals and for coursing; these included several dogs named Flush. Mitford records that one brown spaniel anmed Flush accompanied her father into a Reading theatre: Flush, with his paws on the front of the box, his large earnest eyes fixed on the actors, and his long silky ears brought forward on either side of his face, as is the custom of those intelligent dogs on great occasions, looked and listened all through the piece with a sedate fixity of attention, which greatly endangered the gravity of the persons on the stage.

item.name: pug
Canis familiaris
Canis
Canidae
item.note: Companion animal bred in China and popularized in European courts from the 16th century and later by Queen Victoria. Small dog with a wrinkly, short-haired coat, distinctive short muzzle, and curly tail. They are mostly light brown or red (fawn or apricot) with black markings. Until the 1860s, when more compact, shorter-legged Chinese pugs were imported, English pugs were longer, leaner, and less stocky. European pugs may have been bred with another popular royal lapdog breed, the King Charles spaniel, which contributed to the shorter muzzles of that breed. A fictional pug name Daphne appears in one of the Mitford's stories; this dog is described as a particularly ugly, noisy pug, that barked at every body that came into the house, and bit at most.

item.name: greyhound
Canis familiaris
Canis
Canidae
item.note: A sighthound originally bred for coursing game using their acute vision, agility, and speed. Later employed as a sporting dog for racing. A tall, shorted-haired slender dog with long muzzle, legs and tail, and a characteristic S-shaped body. May have a variety of coat colors including blue (grey), white, black, red, light tan (fawn) or black; and may also have patterned markings such as spots or brindle coats. Traditionally leashed in pairs for coursing and in groups of three for other types of hunting. English greyhouds may have been imported into Europe and the UK with the Romans. The Webbs bred greyhounds and coursed hares with them with the Mitfords. The Mitford family owned many greyhounds, including May-Fly, Mossy, and Miranda.

item.name: domestic guineafowl
Numida meleagris
Numida
Numididae
item.note: The helmeted guineafowl, native to subSaharan Africa, is also raised domestically as a game bird for meat and eggs. Males are called roosters and females are called hens.

item.name: peacock
Pavo cristatus
Pavo
Phasianidae
item.note: Native to the Indian subcontinent, widely introduced as domestic birds elsewhere. In the 19th century, kept in zoos and menageries as well as living ornaments to large gardens and estates. Domestic birds may be raised for meat, and their shed tailfeathers are prized for decorative uses. Omnivorous foragers that roost at night, feral birds can adapt to human habitation, roosting on buildings and foraging discarded food and other refuse. Males are known as peacocks and females as peahens, although both are commonly referred to as peacocks.

item.name: turkey
Meleagris gallopavo domesticus
Meleagris
Phasianidae
item.note: Large domestic fowl raised as poultry. Breeds descend from a subspecies from central Mexico, domesticated by ancient Mesoamericans and imported by the Spanish into Europe. Brought to England in the 16th century and imported back to North America with British colonization. Remained a rare, luxury holiday meat in the UK until the 20th century; goose or beef were more common.

item.name: goose
Anser anser domesticus
Anser
Anatidae
item.note: Large domestic waterfowl raised as poultry. Kept for their eggs, meat, and feathers, they may also be used as guard or watch animals. One of the earliest domesticated birds. In Europe, domestic breeds descend from the wild greylag goose.
c

item.name: chicken
Gallus domesticus
Gallus
Phasianidae
item.note: Domesticated birds kept as livestock and used for meat, eggs, and feathers. Descended from species of Southeast Asian wild junglefowl. First domesticated for ceremonial use and cockfighting, then kept for food in the Middle East and then in Europe, beginning about the 4th century B.C.

item.name: cat
Felis catus
Felis
Felidae
item.note: Now, as in Mitford's time, cats may be classed as domestic (kept as companion animals and for indoor pest control), farm (kept outdoors and in barns or even on ships for rodent control), or feral (wild). Domesticated around 7500 B.C. in Western Asia and likely brought to England by the Romans or other early traders. While frequently kept for rodent control, cats did not become common companion animals in England until the eighteenth century. British Shorthair and Scottish fold breeds are considered to have originated in the UK. Around 1819, the Mitfords owned a tabby named Poll and a long-haired white cat name Selim, likely a Turkish Angora.

item.name: rabbit
xxx
xxx
xxx
item.note: df

item.name: squirrel
Sciurus vulgaris
Sciurus
Sciuridae
item.note: Tree squirrel with tufted ears native to Europe, Asia, and the UK. North American red squirrels are pine squirrels, genus Tamiasciurus, a different genus and species.

item.name: brown trout
Salmo trutta
Salmo
Salmonidae
item.note: The only trout native to the UK, their native range extends from Norway in the north, west to Iceland and east to the Aral Sea. Varieties include sea-run forms, which return to fresh water to spawn; river trout, and lake trout. British angling works refer to this species. Other species of trout were not introduced into the UK until the late 19th century.

item.name: brown rat
Rattus norvegicus
Rattus
Muridae
item.note: Large grey-brown rodent with a scaly tail, an omnivorous burrowing rat that prefers damp habitats and so is well-adapted to human habitation since the Industrial Revolution, including brick and tile buildings and sewers. The most common rat in Europe and North America, likely originiating in north or central Asia. Called the Norway rat or the Hanover rat from erroneous beliefs about their origin outside the UK. Written evidence exists of their presence in Europe by the 1550s and in the UK by the early eighteenth century, becoming widespread by the early 19th century. Fancy (pet) rats and laboratory rats are domesticated subspecies of this wild rat.

item.name: black rat
Rattus rattus
Rattus
Muridae
item.note: Medium-sized black to light brown rodent with a lighter underside and a scaly tail, an omnivorous arboreal rat that prefers dry habitats and so is well-adapted to pre-industrial human settings, including wood and thatched buildings. The most common rat in Europe and North America from the Roman conquest to the eighteenth century, likely originiating in southeast Asia. Displaced by the larger brown rat through increased urbanization, industrialization, and pest control. Now nearly eradicated in the UK.

item.name: common European adder
Vipera berus berus
Vipera
Viperidae
item.note: Venomous snake widespread throughout Eurasia and the UK. They are not particularly dangerous to humans; they are not aggressive and bites are seldom fatal. Also called the cross adderfor the diamond patterns on its back, although melanated individuals may appear entirely brown-black with no visible patterning. One of three snakes native to the UK; the other two are nonvenmous: the barred grass snake and the smooth snake. They have adapted to a wide range of land habitats such as meadows, rough commons and hedgerows, and the edges of woodlands, although they require complex habitats to support basking, hunting for small mammals, amphibians, and insects; protection from predators, and hibernation. The name is derived from the generic word for serpent in Germanic languages, the same term used for snakes and the Devil in the Old Testament. The myth of the deaf adder has its source in Psalms 58: 4 and became proverbial for someone willfully refusing to hear by the early 17th century.

item.name: wisteria
Wisteria
Fabaceae
item.note: Woody climbing bine bearing cascading purple flower plumes, native to Asia and to the eastern US.

item.name: azalea
Rhododendron
Ericaceae
item.note: Flowering shrub carrying abundantly showy red, pink, or white blooms in spring, related to rhododendrons. Grow in the understory of woodlands, and have been hybridized as garden shrubs for hundreds of years. Native to Eurasia and North America. Introduced to the UK in the 19th century as a garden ornamental, it is now considered an invasive species.

item.name: rhododendron
Rhododendron ponticum
Rhododendron
Ericaceae
item.note: Flowering shrub carrying abundantly showy round flower clusters in shades of mauve or lavendar blooms in spring, related to rhododendrons. Grow in the understory of woodlands, and have been hybridized as garden shrubs for hudreds of years. Native to Eurasia and North America. Introduced to the UK in the 18th century as a garden ornamental, it is now considered an invasive species.

item.name: cottongrass
Eriophorum angustifolium
Eriophorum
Cyperaceae
item.note: Sedge that develops fluffy white heads.

item.name: heart's-ease
Viola tricolor
Viola
Violaceae
item.note: Wild pansy native to the UK

item.name: common snowdrop
Galanthus nivalis
Galanthus
Amaryllidaceae
item.note: Small white-flowered plant propagated by bulbs, native to Europe and the Middle East and widely naturalized elsewhere. Believed to be native to the UK since the 16th century. Flowers in late winter and early spring, around the vernal equinox and so is considered a harbinger of spring. May also symbolize purity, hope, or the Christian Holy Trinity. A frequent subject of 19th century poetry including works by Landon Wordsworth, and others.

item.name: hepatica
Anemone hepatica
Anemone
Ranunculaceae
item.note: Low-growing flowering plant with fleshy, trilobal leaves and blue, purple, or pink flowers with showy white stamens. Flowers in late winter and early spring. Native to Europe and Asian and naturalized as well as grown as a garden plant in the UK.

item.name: winter aconite
Eranthis hyemalis
Eranthis
Ranunculaceae
item.note: Yellow flowering plant native to Europe and naturalized in the UK. One of the earliest woodland wildflowers, appearing in late winter. Unrelated to aconitum (monkshood).

item.name: fuchsia
fuchsia magellanica
fuchsia
Onagraceae
item.note: Small upright or spreading flowering shrub, with showy, pendulous bi-colored blooms in combinations of red, pink, purple, and white sepals and petals. A large genus, native to the Carribbean islands, Mexico, central and South America. Now a widely grown garden shrub and pot plant. F. coccinea and F. magellanica, both from South America, were being cultivated in England by the late eighteenth century. Vineyard Gardens in Hammersmith, England introduced fuchsias to the gardening public, as well as introducing and popularizing imports such as the China rose and dahlia as garden plants.

item.name: garden mignonette
Reseda odorata
Reseda
Resedaceae
item.note: Tall, thin pale yellow flower spike growing from base leaves. Native to Europe, the Mediterranean region, and southwest Asia. In the 19th century, grown in gardens and windowboxes for its fragrance. Also used in perfumery, potpourri, and as a cut flower in arrangements. R. luteola, another species, was a source of yellow dye.

item.name: hop-bines
Humulus lupulus
Humulus
Cannabaceae
item.note: Twining plant using stiff, hairy stems (bines) to climb. Flowers of the female plants are the source of hops, used in brewing to flavor beer

item.name: common wallflower
Erysimum cheiri
Erysimum
Brassicaceae
item.note: Flowering plant native to the Mediterranean basin and widely used as a garden plant for its showy, fragrant clusters of racemes in yellow-orange.

item.name: common myrtle
Myrtus communis
Myrtus
Myrtaceae
item.note: Evergreen flowering shrub bearing white flowers with many showy white stamens and dark blue edible berries. Native to the Mediterranean region and western Asia to India. Associated with Jewish, Greek, and Roman ritual and myth, symbolizing honor, prosperity, hope, and love. In early-modern Europe, the flowers became traditional in bride's bouquets because of their associations with love and happiness.

item.name: common buttercup
Ranunculus acris
Ranunculus
Ranunculaceae
item.note: Perennial wildflower of medium height with small, shiny yellow flowers with prominent green or yellow sepals. Native to Eurasia but widely naturalized elsewhere.

item.name: ranunculus
Ranunculus asiaticus
Ranunculus
Ranunculaceae
item.note: A species of buttercup (Ranunculus) native to the eastern Mediterranean region in southwestern Asia, southeastern Europe (Crete, Karpathos and Rhodes), and northeastern Africa. Double-flowered forms, which are likely hybrids, are a popular ornamental plant in gardens, and widely used in floristry.

item.name: potato
Solanum
Solanum tuberosum
Solanaceae
item.note: Potatoes are relatively new to Europe at this time. They are native to the Andes and were introduced only in the second half of the 16th century by the Spanish.

item.name: tuberose
Polianthes xxx
Polianthes
Asparagaceae
item.note: A perennial plant that is frequently used in perfumes.

bibl.note: Sonnet 17 in the 1827 collection (page 310). Also appeared in Marshall's Christmas Box in 1831.

bibl.note: Sonnet 16 in the 1827 collection (page 309). Appeared in the 1821 New Monthly Magazine as Sonnet. On a Landscape by Mr. Hofland(page 392). Later appeared in the 1827 Literary Souvenir (page 233).

bibl.title: To a Friend on Her Birthday [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 15 in the 1827 collection (page 308). Also appeared in the 1822 New Monthly Magazine (page 369) signed M.

bibl.title: The Fishing-Seat, Whiteknights [1827 version]

bibl.note: Sonnet 14 in the 1827 collection (page 307). Also appeared in the 1827 Literary Souvenir (page 287).

bibl.title: On Hearing Mr. Talfourd Plead in the Assize-Hall at Reading, On His First Circuit, March 1821 [1827 version]

bibl.note: Sonnet 13 in the 1827 collection (page 306).

bibl.title: On Two of Mr. Hofland's Landscapes [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 12 in the 1827 collection (page 305).

bibl.title: New Year's Day. 1819 [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 11 in the 1827 collection (page 304).

bibl.title: Englefield House [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 10 in the 1827 collection (page 303).

bibl.title: To Mr. Haydon, On a Study From Nature [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 9 in the 1827 collection (page 302). Also appeared in the July 19, 1817 Literary Gazette as To Mr. Haydon dated 21st May, 1817 (page 41).

bibl.title: To Miss Porden: On Her Poem of COEUR DE LION [1827 version]

bibl.title: On a Beautiful Woman [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 7 in the 1827 collection (page 300). Also appeared in the 1822 New Monthly Magazine as Sonnet. (page 192).

bibl.title: To My Mother Sleeping [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 6 in the 1827 collection (page 299).

bibl.title: Written July, 1824 [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 5 in the 1827 collection (page 298).

Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 4 in the 1827 collection (pages 296-97).

bibl.title: The Forget-Me-Not [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 3 in the 1827 collection (page 295).

bibl.title: On Mr. Hofland's Picture of Jerusalem at the Time of the Crucifixion [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 2 in the 1827 collection (page 294). Also appeared in the 1826 Amulet as Sonnet: Jerusalem (page 329).

bibl.title: Written in a Blank-Paper Book Given to the Author by a Friend [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 1 in the 1827 collection (page 293). Also appeared in the 1821 New Monthly Magazine as Sonnet. Written in a Blank Paper Book Given To the Author by a Friend(page 387).
